splashscreen.title: Satellites for Peat's Sake
splashscreen.subtitle: Flow Country, Scotland
splashscreen.altText: Satellites for Peat's Sake in Flow Country, Scotland

slides.text: Peatlands make up just 3% of land globally but capture twice as much carbon dioxide as all forests combined. In healthy bogs, peat moss does not fully decay, and instead slowly builds up to form layers of carbon-rich peat. However, if the bog dries out, or is damaged by fire, the carbon is released – adding to the effects of climate change.

The Flow Country is the largest remaining expanse of blanket bog in Europe, and it is estimated that the carbon stored equals 100 years’ worth of Scotland’s fossil fuel emissions. Satellite imagery can be used to create maps of peatlands, measure soil moisture, and detect disturbances such as fires, making it cheaper and easier to monitor and preserve these valuable landscapes

slides.caption: This satellite image mosaic, from 28 May 2018, offers a cloud-free view over Scotland's Flow Country. (ESA)

Fire burned 5,700 hectares of peatland in 2019. This image was taken on 16 May. (ESA)
